items.message: River levels are steadily falling at the Little Alne river gauge, however, the risk of flooding remains. Further light showers are forecast this evening and overnight, 09/10/2024. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. River levels have now peaked and are beginning to fall on the upper Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook. Flooding is possible through Wednesday and into Thursday.

Flooding may affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon and Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge.

We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary. Drier conditions are expected from Wednesday afternoon and the situation should improve.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

This message will be updated by 02:00 PM on 10/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are falling but remain responsive to further rainfall. This information is correct as of 3:30pm on Wednesday 9 October. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 51 centimetres of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has approximately 68 centimetres of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, Thursday 10 October 2024.

items.message: The Flood Alert for the Upper Mole is no longer in force. The river level is now falling. Further rain showers are expected today 09/10/2024 but this is unlikely to cause any flooding.  We will re issue this flood alert if required.

The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are still higher than normal, but are now slowly falling. Minor flooding could continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens in Crowhurst, and possibly Bexhill Road Recreation Ground. Scattered showers are forecast Wednesday evening, with very little rainfall predicted for the rest of the week. The river should continue to fall, and will have returned nearer to normal in Crowhurst by Thursday morning 10/10/2024. River levels in Bulverhythe will remain higher than normal for longer, probably until next week. With unsettled weather forecast in the outlook, flood protection products are recommended to be kept close by in Crowhurst, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding is thought possible.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.92 m. The drain level is 7.22 m and rising slowly. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3 m.

Scattered showers are possible today and tomorrow, but dry weather is forecast for Friday and through the weekend.

We are currently unable to pump due to the high river levels, but we have opened the Parrett Relief Channel to help reduce these. Pumping activities will commence as soon as the river levels allow.

We are monitoring the situation closely. Do not attempt to drive, cycle or walk through flood water, and be careful using footpaths near local watercourses and flooded areas. Refer to @TravelSomerset for local road closures.
 
This message will be updated by 4PM tomorrow, Thursday 10/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.

Following heavy rainfall yesterday, the water level in the River Blackwater and Cadnam River remains elevated but is slowly returning to normal. Over the last three weeks we have recorded over two months’ worth of rain (154mm) so the river catchment is highly responsive. Today (Wednesday 09/10/24) and tomorrow (Thursday 10/10/24), a small amount of rain is forecast (up to 10mm) each day. This may cause a small rise in the river level over the next 48 hours, but is not expected to cause significant impacts. This flood alert is likely to be removed by 11:00 tomorrow (Thursday 10/10/24).

items.description: River Anker at Mancetter, Witherley and Atherstone
items.message: River levels remain high, but are steadily falling at the Mancetter river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall last night. Consequently, flooding of property is still expected this evening and overnight, 09/10/2024. We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in the areas around Lodge Close in Mancetter, Bridge Lane and Riverside in Witherley, Royal Meadow Drive, Ratcliffe Road and Aldermill Business Park in Atherstone. Further light showers are forecast this evening and overnight 09/10/2024. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 10/10/2024. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please move family, pets, possessions, valuables and cars to safety and activate any property flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers. This message will be updated by 11:00 10/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

Flooding of property is not expected at this stage. Please avoid driving or walking through floodwater.

Weather conditions are expected to continue to improve, with some light scattered showers possible overnight. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.

This message will be updated by 10:00am on 10th October 2024, or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are high following intense rain on Tuesday evening. In Hellingly, flooding is expected to continue to affect properties on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road. The Cuckmere River at Cowbeech has already fallen significantly, flood impacts on Mill Lane, Hellingly, and Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm should reduce. Flooding is also expected to continue to affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Scattered showers are possible Wednesday, but with very little rainfall through to the weekend. The Bull River in Hellingly should begin to fall by 14:00 09/10/2024, and return nearer to a normal level by Thursday evening. The Cuckmere River in Alfriston should begin to fall by 23:00 09/10/2024, but could remain higher than normal until Friday. Please plan to avoid driving on routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 13:00 10/10/2024.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

The River Uck is still high in Isfield, where minor flood impacts will continue to affect fields, gardens, and roads on Wednesday evening. However, river levels all along the River Uck are now falling, and flood impacts will reduce. In Buxted and Uckfield, river levels have already fallen significantly, and only minimal flood impacts are expected to remain, affecting fields, gardens, and roads. Scattered showers are forecast Wednesday, with very little rainfall predicted for the rest of the week. The river should continue to fall, and will have returned nearer to normal all along the River Uck by Thursday morning 10/10/2024. Please keep flood protection products close by for future use, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding is thought possible.

The Western Rother is high and rising between Selham and Fittleworth, following persistent rain on Tuesday. From 18:00 09/10/2024 minor flood impacts could affect fields, rural roads, and gardens of mill properties at Lodsbridge, near Selham and in Fittleworth. River levels through Liss, Iping, and Midhurst have either already peaked, or will not rise much higher, and no flood impacts are expected upstream of Midhurst. Only minimal flood impacts are expected on the River Lod too. Only scattered showers are forecast Wednesday, and very little rain predicted through to and including the weekend. However, the river is unlikely to begin to fall near Selham until 22:00 09/10/2024, and midday Thursday 10/10/2024 in Fittleworth. River levels will be slow to fall, and might not return nearer to normal until the weekend. Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 14:00 10/10/2024

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

We are constantly monitoring river levels and this message will be updated on Thursday morning or earlier if the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising. Nearly half a month's rain (30mm) was recorded at Cowbeech on Tuesday, most of which fell in only a couple of hours. Flooding will continue to affect properties in Alfriston, including The Old Clergy House, Deans Place Hotel, and properties near North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane. Flooding will also be extensive through fields, rural roads, gardens, and access along Litlington Road may be restricted by flood water. Scattered showers are forecast Wednesday evening, with very little rain over the rest of the week. The river is unlikely to begin to fall until 22:00 09/10/2024, at the earliest. The river might not return nearer to a normal level until Friday 11/10/2024. River levels are expected to peak higher than they have in recent weeks. Flood water can be deep and dangerous, please take care if walking near the river in Alfriston. Please plan to avoid driving on routes vulnerable to flooding, including North Street. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 21:00 10/10/2024.

River levels remain high at the Tewkesbury Upper Pound river gauge and are rising at the Mythe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 09/10/24. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill. 
Predicted peaks:- Mythe 2.6m to 2.9m Thursday evening, 10/10/24. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 8am on 10/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

We continue to monitor the situation.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

River levels on the Lower River Rother remain high following recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk of flooding are low-lying land and roads around surrounding Woodhouse Mill.
No further significant rainfall is expected over the coming days, so river levels will gradually decrease.  We continue to monitor the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated as the situation changes.

items.message:

River levels on watercourses in the River Till and tributaries have dropped after the recent persistent and heavy rainfall.

items.description: River Dene in South East Warwickshire
items.message: River levels remain high but are steadily falling at the Walton river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Further light showers are forecast this evening and overnight 09/10/2024. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 11:00, 10/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Brue and Glastonbury Millstream from Lovington to Highbridge, low lying properties
items.message: This Flood Warning met criteria for a few hours overnight. The River Brue levels have now dropped and the warning can be removed, although a Flood Alert currently remains for the catchment. Showers only are forecast for later today.

This flood alert is no longer in force. River levels on Wash Dike have risen in response to last night’s rainfall however remain below levels of concern.
Further showers are expected until 10am today, 09/10/2024, following which weather conditions are expected to improve and no further significant rainfall is expected over the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation and will re-issue this flood alert if necessary.

River levels are high but beginning to fall in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is possible over the next few hours and into this evening, 09/10/2024. Areas most at risk are around Alconbury Brook at Hamerton, The Alconburys, Little Stukeley and Brampton. You are advised to move cars out of these flood risk areas. Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours which will keep river levels high. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. 
We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, 10/10/2024.

items.description: Bristol Avon (upper) from Malmesbury to Chippenham
items.message: The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible. Weather conditions are expected to improve with drier weather forecast through the week and the situation is expected to improve through the week. We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message:
This flood alert has been removed as there is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.

Further rainfall is forecast overnight but no further flooding is expected.

There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary. The flood gates at Croft will remain closed for the time being. 

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Bristol Avon (upper) from Chippenham to Melksham
items.message:
River levels have now peaked and are beginning to fall on the upper Bristol Avon. Water levels remain high and there remains a possibility of continued flooding.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around properties at Reybridge.

Weather conditions are expected to improve with drier conditions expected for the remainder of the week, river levels are expected to continue to fall. We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary.

Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 10/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: River levels are falling and are now below the flood risk threshold. The forecast is for light showers through today, Wednesday 9th October, but some of these could be heavy at times. After today the outlook is drier for the next few days into the weekend. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

This Flood Alert has been issued as river levels in the Seven catchment have risen in response to heavy rainfall last night and today Wednesday, 9th October 2024. Areas most at risk include low lying land, roads and footpaths around the River Seven, around Sinnington and to the east of Normanby, as well as tributaries including Northdale Beck, Hartoft Beck, Ings Beck, Lastingham Beck, Sutherland Beck, Cropton Beck and Catter Beck. The river is expected to peak shortly but more showers are forecast tonight and a further rise is expected. Levels are not forecast to reach levels of significant concern. We are closely monitoring the situation. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00am on Thursday, 10/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from 4pm this afternoon, Wednesday 9th October, and for at least the next 24hrs. Water levels are higher due to recent rainfall entering the Broads system being held up by a surge from a low pressure system within the North Sea. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas. We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message tomorrow morning, Thursday 10th October, or as the situation changes.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 1:45am and 3:45am on Thursday 10th October 2024. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions from a low-pressure system in the North Sea. We expect high tide levels at the harbourside in Southwold. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Lowestoft of 1.63 mAODN at 2:45am, on Thursday 10th October, which is 0.84m above tide tables, wind Force 7, Northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables). We are not currently expecting to issue any further flood alerts for this area. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10am on Thursday 10th October.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 3:45am and 5:45am, on Thursday 10th October 2024. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions from a low-pressure system in the North Sea. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.51 mAODN at 4:45am, on Thursday 10th October, which is 0.97m above tide tables, wind Force 5, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables).  We are not currently expecting to issue any further flood alerts for this area. Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 10am on Thursday 10th October.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Blackwater as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected this evening 09/10/24, especially in the Swallowfield area. Further outbreaks of rain are forecast overnight. We expect river levels to slowly rise until tomorrow morning 10/10/24. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 10/10/24, or as the situation changes.
